author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: betrothal
description: This word has appeared in 10 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word betrothal has appeared in 10 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 27 in “‘Polite Society’ Review: Pride and Plenty of Fists” by Amy Nicholson:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis and Jason Horowitz
title: How New Democracy Surged to Victory in Greece
description: Voters seemed to embrace Kyriakos Mitsotakis’s approach to the economy and tough stance on migration, and were less concerned about revelations of spying on the opposition.
content: Kyriakos Mitsotakis, the leader of the conservative New Democracy party who has presided over a period of economic stability and tough anti-migration policies in Greece, was sworn in on Monday for a second term as prime minister after a landslide victory that gave him a clear mandate for the next four years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: Congestion Pricing Plan in New York City Clears Final Federal Hurdle
description: The program, which could begin next year, would charge drivers to enter Midtown Manhattan, with the revenues going to improve mass transit.
content: Congestion pricing in New York City has cleared its final federal hurdle, officials said on Monday, all but ensuring that the first such program in the nation will begin next year with the aim of reducing traffic and pollution in Manhattan and funding improvements to mass transit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai and Ian Willms
title: Olivia Chow Elected New Mayor of Toronto, Out of 102 Candidates
description: Once considered an affordable model city, Toronto’s new mayor will be tested by the same issues confronting other big hubs that are trying to recover from the pandemic.
content: Voters in Toronto chose Olivia Chow, a left-leaning, veteran politician, as their new mayor at a moment when the city is confronting a litany of issues that are also facing other urban powerhouses trying to rebound from the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Jury to Decide Fate of Deputy Who Did Not Confront Parkland Gunman
description: A Florida jury began deliberations in the case against Scot Peterson, in a rare trial against a police officer over inaction in a school shooting.
content: A Florida jury will soon decide if a former police officer should be convicted of crimes for failing to confront the gunman who killed 17 people and wounded 17 others at a Parkland high school five years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: French Montana Lists His Los Angeles Mansion
description: The seven-bedroom house also has garages for five cars, a game room and a wine cellar, but the rapper is ready to move on and diversify his real estate portfolio.
content: Karim Kharbouch, better known by his stage name French Montana, is bidding adieu to his 1.35-acre compound in Los Angeles’s exclusive Hidden Hills neighborhood, asking $22.75 million for the seven-bedroom, nine-bath home in one of the city’s most celebrity-studded communities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The Bachelorette’ and ‘Casa Susanna’
description: The 20th season of the reality dating show premieres on ABC, and PBS presents a documentary about a safe home for trans women in the ‘50s and ’60s.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, June 26 — July 2. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller, Noah Weiland and Carl Zimmer
title: U.S. Vaccine Program Now Flush With Cash, but Short on Key Details
description: A $5 billion federal program aims to make better Covid vaccines. But vaccine makers are confused by murky regulatory guidance.
content: Efforts to develop the next generation of Covid vaccines are running up against bureaucratic hassles and regulatory uncertainty, scientists say, obstacles that could make it harder to curb the spread of the coronavirus and arm the United States against future pandemics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: A Mutiny That Showed the Stress on Putin’s System of Rule
description: A member of Russia’s elite marched on his rivals, with a mercenary army at his back, suggesting that Vladimir V. Putin’s grip over a coalition of powerful figures may be more brittle than it appeared.
content: Since it began last year, Russia’s war in Ukraine has hinged not just on battlefield results, but also a question in Moscow: Could President Vladimir V. Putin’s grip on power withstand the strain of fighting a long and costly war, with no end in sight?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: Delaware Lawmaker Aims to Be First Openly Transgender House Member
description: Sarah McBride is no stranger to firsts: In 2012, she became the first openly transgender person to work at the White House, during the Obama administration.
content: State Senator Sarah McBride announced on Monday that she would run for Delaware’s at-large U.S. House seat — a bid that, if successful, would make her the first openly transgender member of the U.S. Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Dan Higgins
title: A High-Profile Primary Tests Black Buffalo’s Political Power Structure
description: Zeneta Everhart, whose son was gravely wounded in the racist mass shooting in Buffalo, and India Walton, who nearly unseated the city’s mayor, are facing off on Tuesday.
content: BUFFALO — They are two of the most prominent Black women in Buffalo politics: India Walton, a celebrated progressive insurgent, jarred by a painful election loss; and Zeneta Everhart, a rising newcomer, galvanized by a singular terrifying event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Supreme Court Steps Aside in Fight Over Louisiana’s Congressional Maps
description: The justices returned the case to a lower court on Monday, raising the chances that the state will soon be required to create a second district that empowers Black voters to select a representative.
content: The Supreme Court cleared the way on Monday for a challenge to Louisiana’s congressional map to advance, raising the chances that the state will soon be required to create a second district that empowers Black voters to select a representative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Asia Society Names New Leader
description: Yasufumi Nakamori, a curator at the Tate, will be director of the New York museum showcasing Asian art, artifacts and culture.
content: Yasufumi Nakamori, a senior curator of international art at the Tate Modern in London, will become director of the Asia Society in New York, the museum announced Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: A Renowned Economist’s New Idea for Stopping Climate Change
description: Carbon-linked bonds could save carbon pricing from its fatal flaw.
content: Robert Litterman is a legend on Wall Street. He earned a doctorate in economics from the University of Minnesota in 1980. In his 23 years at Goldman Sachs he oversaw quants, managed risk and developed, with the great applied mathematician Fischer Black, the Black-Litterman model for portfolio allocation. Now he’s a founding partner and the risk manager at Kepos Capital, a New York-based investment company with $2 billion under management.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: A Big Leaguer Lost His Fastball but Not His Will to Compete
description: Julio Teheran’s journey from All-Star to the independent leagues and back has been crucial for the Brewers. It doesn’t matter that he can’t break 90 miles per hour.
content: Julio Teheran is a big leaguer. This is a statement of fact, because he pitches for the Milwaukee Brewers now, and not the Staten Island FerryHawks, as he did last season. But it’s also an identity, a presence. Many players wear a major league uniform, but not all have the moxie to go with it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo and Derek Arthur
title: We All Live in ‘South Park’ Now
description: Farhad Manjoo on how the offensive cartoon encapsulates America.
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts and narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows that we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: Trump Campaigns in Michigan, a Battleground That’s Tinted Blue
description: With their party out of power, some Republicans in the state are worried that the former president could cost Michigan its status as a swing state.
content: In front of a sold-out crowd on Sunday evening in Novi, Mich., former President Donald J. Trump lamented the decline of the automobile industry under Democratic rule and said he “stood up to China” to save thousands of manufacturing jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Sprinting Toward Running’s Red Carpet
description: The fashion runway to the locker room has become ubiquitous in professional sports like basketball and football. Can the walk into a running event become the same thing?
content: A few hours before some of the world’s fastest runners would run a few hundred meters very quickly, they were invited to walk some 30 meters very slowly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Badger
title: The Uneven Effect of Remote Work, in One List
description: This ranking of jobs by percentage of remote work also helps explain why the pandemic has left more scars in certain areas.
content: Since the start of the pandemic, economists have extensively studied the effects of remote work on many facets of life, including office demand and the housing market. And, well, writers like those of us at The Upshot have extensively written about all of this, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: ‘National Dish’ Charts a World Tour of Iconic Dishes
description: New American-made Lodge Dutch ovens, a sake recommendation service and more food news.
content: The way the food writer Anya von Bremzen sees it, many cuisines can be defined by iconic dishes. In her latest book, “National Dish,” she examines six of them through a personal lens while consulting a gaggle of experts, from academics to local butchers. Beginning with French pot-au-feu in a country of richly globalized cooking, she moves on to Naples (pizza and pasta), Tokyo (ramen and rice), Seville (tapas and the ingredients they require), Oaxaca (maize, mole and mezcal), Istanbul (mezze and more), and her native Russia and also Ukraine (borscht). The histories of essential ingredients, how they flourished in particular countries and her connection to the various cultures are woven throughout this compelling read. The cover is illustrated by Roz Chast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: The Dangerous Heat Wave Will Continue to Bake the U.S. This Week
description: Oppressive heat will expand out of Texas to blanket an area from Arizona to Alabama.
content: The South is in the middle of a wave of record heat expected to continue through the July 4 holiday. A stubborn heat dome of high pressure over Texas that has kept heat indexes at dangerous levels for several days is forecast to shift slightly to the east this week, bringing continued hot weather to Louisiana, Mississippi and Alabama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin and Mary Beth Gahan
title: Teen and Stepfather Die on Hike in Near-Record Texas Heat
description: The high-pressure “heat dome” that has engulfed Texas and Oklahoma for several days is forecast to shift eastward this week, bringing dangerous temperatures to the Gulf States.
content: A teenage boy and his stepfather hiking in Big Bend National Park in Texas died as temperatures there rose to 119 degrees Fahrenheit on Friday — the second-highest mark ever recorded in the state — during a triple-digit heat wave that was forecast to spread to the Southeast this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Day Care for Less Than $10: How Canada Is Easing the Burden for Parents
description: A national program is reducing day care fees to as low as 10 Canadian dollars, about $7.60, per day, a relief for families even as a surge in demand has created obstacles.
content: As Susana Ibarra’s maternity leave was ending and she was preparing to return to her office outside Toronto, she still faced a big challenge: finding care for her son and then figuring out how to pay for it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: Publishers Clearing House Pays $18.5 Million in ‘Dark Patterns’ Suit
description: The case comes less than a week after the Federal Trade Commission sued Amazon, which was accused of similar deceptive practices.
content: Publishers Clearing House, the direct marketing company that uses sweepstakes to sell magazine subscriptions, agreed on Monday to pay $18.5 million to settle a lawsuit brought by the Federal Trade Commission, which accused the company of using what’s known as dark patterns to trick customers into paying for products or giving up their data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Jesse McReynolds, Lead Singer in Long-Running Bluegrass Duo, Dies at 93
description: Also a mandolinist, he performed alongside his brother, Jim, in an act that lasted 55 years. He continued performing after his brother’s death.
content: Jesse McReynolds, who for 55 years was the lead singer and mandolin player with the first-generation bluegrass duo Jim & Jesse, died on Friday at his home in Gallatin, Tenn. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Farro With Blistered Tomatoes and Pesto Is a Half-Hour Hero
description: Also on the table in 30 minutes (or less): grilled tofu tacos, jerk chicken meatballs and a very versatile ginger-dill salmon.
content: One of the unsung heroes of my prodigious pantry is the pesto in the freezer (I consider my freezer to be part of the pantry). It might not be as chic as chili crisp or as multitask-y as mayo, yet it adds an herby, garlicky brightness to all kinds of meals and requires no extra work (unless you made the pesto yourself and froze it, in which case, yay past you!).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Parental Incarceration Is a Silent American Epidemic More Common Than Childhood Asthma
description: We are honoring the Top 11 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Joshua Martoma, age 17.
content: This essay, by Joshua Martoma, age 17, from Pine Crest School in Boca Raton, Fla., is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s 10th Annual Student Editorial Contest, for which we received 12,592 entries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liana Satenstein
title: Flipping Out
description: In danger of scrolling her life away, a writer gets a vintage cellphone.
content: I started flirting with the idea of getting a flip phone while watching a TikTok livestream of someone shaving a grape at 2 a.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: How to Stay Safe in California’s Roaring Rivers This Summer
description: Melt water from the snowpack that piled up in the Sierra Nevada over a stormy winter has turned normally tame rivers into deadly, raging torrents.
content: It’s officially summer, and for lots of Californians — particularly those who live many miles inland from the beach — that usually means it’s river season: a time for seeking relief from the heat in cool water, wading in shallows or floating in inner tubes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Why We Should Be Fans of Fan Fiction
description: We are honoring the Top 11 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Megan Ray, age 16.
content: This essay, by Megan Ray, age 16, from Maynard High School in Maynard, Mass., is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s 10th Annual Student Editorial Contest, for which we received 12,592 entries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Mary Wilson, Alex Stern, Will Reid, M.J. Davis Lin, Patricia Willens, Lisa Chow, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: A 36-Hour Rebellion in Russia
description: What does the brief mutiny by the Wagner mercenary force tell us about the future of political power in the country?
content: An armed rebellion in Russia over the weekend stunned the world and amounted to the single biggest challenge to President Vladimir V. Putin’s rule since he came to power 23 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Eric Schmitt and David Guttenfelder
title: Minefields and Menace: Why Ukraine’s Pushback Is Off to a Halting Start
description: The Ukrainian Army is encountering an array of challenges that has complicated the early stages of its counteroffensive, especially the large swaths of minefields. But its leaders are urging patience, insisting the main push is yet to come.
content: The column of Bradley armored vehicles rumbled forward, filled with Ukrainian soldiers, bringing a new and potent American weapon to the war’s southern front.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood and Christina Goldbaum
title: Pakistan’s Military Fires 3 Commanders, Cracking Down After Khan Protests
description: They were among 18 officers disciplined for their handling of protests by supporters of Imran Khan, a former prime minister, sending a message that support for him would not be tolerated in the ranks.
content: Pakistan’s military on Monday fired three senior army commanders and disciplined 15 top officers over their conduct during recent protests that supported former Prime Minister Imran Khan, in what analysts called the strongest action the military has taken against its own members in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: How to Stop Sweating So Much
description: Excessive swampiness can be an inconvenience, especially in the summer, but several treatments are available.
content: Summer is the season of swimming, sunbathing — and sweating. As the heat index climbs, our bodies work hard to keep us cool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Kelly Clarkson’s ‘Chemistry’ Draws on Familiar Formulas
description: With a big voice and big personal changes to sing about, Clarkson ends up with arrangements that don’t match the power and rawness of the emotions fueling them.
content: When a musician known in part for her fiery breakup anthems announces the dissolution of her marriage, fans can sometimes react with an impolite if somewhat understandable presumption: “Well, at least the divorce album will be good.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Richard Ravitch, Rescuer of the Subways and New York’s Finances, Dies at 89
description: He helped New York City avoid bankruptcy in the mid-1970s, ran the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and later served as lieutenant governor.
content: Richard Ravitch, a politically savvy, civic-minded developer and public citizen who helped rescue New York City from the brink of bankruptcy and its decaying subways from fiscal collapse, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Putin Addresses Russia
description: Also, Pakistan’s military fired three top commanders.
content: President Vladimir Putin addressed the rebellion over the weekend by the Wagner mercenary group, led by Yevgeny Prigozhin, in a short televised speech yesterday. In his first public comments since Saturday, Putin tried to project unity and stability as questions swirled about the strength of his grip on power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass
title: Umbria by Train: A Journey Into the ‘Green Heart of Italy’
description: Three hill towns in this landlocked region offer cultural riches, culinary delights and wondrous views. Here’s how to get to them from Rome and Florence.
content: Calling itself the green heart of Italy, the landlocked region of Umbria is known for its truffles and olive oil, roast pork and sausage, wine and cheese.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Intensifying Rains Pose Hidden Flood Risks Across the U.S.
description: In some of the nation’s most populous areas, hazardous storms can dump significantly more water than previously believed, new calculations show.
content: As climate change intensifies severe rainstorms, the infrastructure protecting millions of Americans from flooding faces growing risk of failures, according to new calculations of expected precipitation in every county and locality across the contiguous United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: Why the 1932 Movie ‘Freaks’ Is a Touchstone for Disability Representation
description: Though it has detractors, scholars and advocates have largely embraced this film for the way it shows people just living their lives while disabled.
content: Hollywood’s track record for portraying people with disabilities has been sketchy at best. There have been inspirational figures, noble martyrs and lovable oddballs — some of these performances garnering Academy Awards — but there aren’t a lot of people simply living their lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Hickley
title: For This Museum, Russian-German Collaboration Got Awkward
description: As a Berlin museum with Russian trustees commemorates an allied victory over the Soviet Union, it is also negotiating the fallout from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
content: As preparations get underway for the 75th anniversary of the Berlin Airlift, a Cold War victory for western allies over a Soviet blockade, one of the museums mounting a commemorative exhibition is negotiating the fallout from a more recent geopolitical conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Brooklyn Academy of Music Lays Off 13 Percent of Its Staff
description: The organization, which made Brooklyn a destination for pathbreaking performances, is reducing programming next season as it seeks to rebound from the pandemic.
content: The Brooklyn Academy of Music, one of the most important cultural organizations in New York, has laid off 13 percent of its staff members and reduced its programming as it seeks to plug a “sizable structural deficit” during a challenging time for the arts, officials confirmed on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: In Poorer Countries, Obesity Can Signal Financial Security
description: A study found that loan officers in Uganda, where information is scarce, were more likely to offer credit to heavier-looking people.
content: In the world’s wealthiest countries, the richer people are, the thinner they tend to be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: Google Pixel Fold Review: Foldable Phones Are Improving
description: Google’s new $1,800 gadget proves that phones with bendable screens are something people might want. Now they just need to get cheaper.
content: When I recently turned on Google’s new Pixel Fold smartphone and unfolded it as if it were a book, it transformed into a miniature tablet, similar to an iPad Mini or an Amazon Fire. Then something unexpected happened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: What Is Happening in the Housing Market?
description: Home construction surged in May and prices have ticked up, even with interest rates at a 15-year high. The resilience has surprised some economists.
content: Gianni Martinez, 31, thought that it would be fairly easy to buy an apartment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: The Buffet Is Back, Stretching Dollars and Slinging Crab Legs
description: These big, communal all-you-can-eat spreads faltered amid pandemic fears, but inflation and a hunger for an experience are giving them new life and variety.
content: The buffet got creamed during the pandemic. Even when diners crept back into restaurants covered in hand sanitizer, a model of eating based on shared serving spoons and food seasoned with the breath of strangers seemed like a goner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Heller
title: 75 Years After ‘The Lottery’ Was Published, the Chills Linger
description: Stephen King, David Sedaris, Carmen Maria Machado and others on how Shirley Jackson’s eerie classic first got under their skin.
content: In its June 26, 1948 issue, The New Yorker published Shirley Jackson’s unsettling story “The Lottery,” and it’s not an overstatement to say that readers freaked out. They wrote letters in droves, angry or unsure about what this slowly unfolding portrait of small-town mob violence was doing in a literary-minded magazine. Now considered an American classic, the story went on to become a classroom mainstay, and a bracing influence on artists prone to see the rot in the flower bed. Here, 75 years later, 13 writers and filmmakers — plus Jackson’s graphic-novelist grandson — recall reading “The Lottery” for the first time, and why it’s stayed with them since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: How the Shortage of a $15 Cancer Drug Is Upending Treatment
description: Older generic chemotherapy drugs remain scarce, forcing doctors to put a priority on the patients who have the best chance of survival.
content: Tony Shepard learned he had vocal cord cancer this spring, but he was encouraged when his doctor said he had an 88 percent chance at a cure with chemotherapy and radiation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Morgan Wallen Enters Adele Territory With 14th Week at No. 1
description: The country singer’s latest album, “One Thing at a Time,” has now notched more weeks atop the Billboard chart than any album in more than a decade.
content: The country star Morgan Wallen is back on the road after six weeks of rest, and back once again at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, notching his 14th nonconsecutive week on top since the release of his latest album, “One Thing at a Time,” in March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Uber Rider Who Killed Driver Said She Thought She Was Being Kidnapped
description: The passenger, who is charged with murder, told the authorities that she shot Daniel Piedra Garcia in the head as she worried he was taking her across the border to Mexico instead of to an El Paso casino.
content: Daniel Piedra Garcia had been an Uber driver for three weeks when he picked up a rider on June 16 who was headed to the Speaking Rock Casino in El Paso. It was near the end of his work day, but Mr. Piedra had picked up the rider anyway, his family said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Franklin
title: 75 Years Ago, ‘The Lottery’ Went Viral. There’s a Reason We’re Still Talking About It.
description: “The Lottery” is a classic short story because of its power to unsettle us. Too bad readers today are losing their appetite for discomfort.
content: On a warm, sunny June morning, village residents gather in the tranquil main square. They’ve assembled to conduct an ancient ritual, the meaning of which has been lost to time. One by one, they draw slips of paper from an old wooden box.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Expectations of ‘Perfect’ English Are Elitist and Unrealistic
description: We are honoring the Top 11 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Megan Luong, age 17.
content: This essay, by Megan Luong, age 17, from Notre Dame High School in San Jose, Calif., is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s 10th Annual Student Editorial Contest, for which we received 12,592 entries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Kamala Harris, at Stonewall, Seeks to Reassure L.G.B.T.Q. Community
description: The vice president visited the Stonewall Inn, a landmark for the gay rights movement, a day after New York’s governor signed a bill to protect transgender youth.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris visited the Stonewall Inn Monday — the site of the 1969 riot viewed as sparking the modern L.G.B.T.Q. rights movement — to pledge her support to the community, lament the threats it faces, and take selfies with the assembled drinkers on the day after the city’s Pride march.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das and Claire Moses
title: Belgium Was Out of Hurdlers. So a Shot-Putter Agreed to Run.
description: Jolien Boumkwo’s 100-meter hurdles debut was not a stunt. Her team needed the points, and she volunteered.
content: The runner to watch was in Lane 2, and she was hard to miss: Jolien Boumkwo of Belgium was a head taller than every other woman in the second heat of the 100-meter hurdles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ori Nir
title: A Dangerous Shift Is Underway in the West Bank
description: Ultranationalist West Bank settlers who have recently attacked Palestinian towns and villages seem to want to wedge out their Palestinian neighbors.
content: In April 1988, as a reporter for Haaretz, I attended the funeral of a 15-year-old West Bank settler, Tirza Porat, who was accidentally shot to death by a fellow settler. Ms. Porat was participating in a hike of teens from a settlement near the city of Nablus when, following a confrontation with Palestinian rock throwers in a nearby village, a young settler opened fire, mistakenly killing Ms. Porat.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: June 26, 2023
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, June 26, 2023.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman and Nicholas Nehamas
title: DeSantis Calls for ‘Deadly Force’ Against Suspected Drug Traffickers
description: Campaigning in a Texas border city, the Florida governor laid out a series of hard-right immigration proposals, including some that would face legal roadblocks or test the limits of presidential authority.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida on Monday proposed a host of hard-right immigration policies, floating the idea of using deadly force against suspected drug traffickers and others breaking through border barriers while “demonstrating hostile intent.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Salary Law Requires Transparency, Up to a Point
description: The law now mandates that companies post salaries, but some are listing broad ranges.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll see how a New York City law that took effect late last year is helping workers entering the job market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: After Cutting Ties With Russia, a Hermitage Museum Outpost Rebrands
description: The Hermitage Amsterdam broke away from its St. Petersburg mother ship and will now be called H’Art Museum, presenting works from the Smithsonian, the Centre Pompidou and the British Museum.
content: In March 2022, a week after Russia launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine, the Hermitage Amsterdam museum severed ties with the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Jesse Watters to Fill Tucker Carlson’s Old Slot as Fox Shuffles Prime-Time Lineup
description: Fox’s prime time ratings have consistently been the highest in cable news but have fallen off by roughly one-third since the network took Mr. Carlson off the air.
content: Fox News shook up its prime-time lineup on Monday in the first major reorganization to its most popular programming since the beginning of the Trump administration. The moves include permanently filling the 8 p.m. slot, which has been vacant since the network canceled Tucker Carlson’s show in April.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: How Short Is Too Short for Men’s Pants?
description: A reader wants to experiment with higher hemlines — but men’s exposed ankles have been a source of fashion world strife.
content: The male ankle! Or mankle. (I love word hybrids.) Of all the body parts to be a source of controversy, this is one of the oddest. Yet the question of whether to show or not to show the masculine talus (the official name of that nobby bone between the tibia, fibula and heel) has been a topic of debate for years. In 2005, Thom Browne, the designer who has almost single-handedly been trying to raise men’s hemlines, told The New York Times that the ankle was “the new male cleavage.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: How Are New Yorkers Handling the Costs of Child Care?
description: The New York Times is interested in exploring how New York City residents are navigating the costs and challenges of care.
content: The New York Times is interested in exploring how New York City residents are handling child care. We are hoping to speak with people about navigating the costs and other challenges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jes Aznar and Mike Ives
title: They Ride and Lasso Like Texans. They Live 8,000 Miles Away.
description: In the Philippines, men and women compete in an annual rodeo that celebrates a thriving cowboy culture with roots in the Spanish and American colonial eras.
content: A honky-tonk twang echoes across a fairground as cowhands wrangle cattle inside a dirt-floored stadium. The scene would be typical in Texas, but this rodeo is happening about 8,000 miles away, on an island in the Philippines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: Murders, on the Decline
description: The recent spike in murders already seems to be over.
content: When murder rates spiked three years ago, experts worried that the U.S. was slipping into a violent era that recalled the period between the 1970s and ’90s. But the data this year offers hope that the increase was temporary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: 14-Story Building Collapses in Egypt, Injuring at Least 4
description: The collapse is one of a several similar disasters in Egypt in recent years. Rescuers were trying to determine if more people were trapped under the rubble.
content: A 14-story apartment building popular with vacationing Egyptians collapsed Monday in Alexandria, Egypt’s second-largest city, and rescuers were working to clear the debris, officials said. At least four people were injured, and others were possibly still missing as of Monday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacey Lastoe
title: Bingeing in Comfort This Summer
description: Dinner and a show — that is, eating in front of the TV — only gets easier with the right furniture and a can-do attitude.
content: The finale of “Succession” might have left die-hard fans wondering what Kendall was going to do with the rest of his life, but everyone else can now turn their attention to the summer television season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wyna Liu
title: How Our New Game, Connections, Is Put Together
description: The editor of the game talks about how she makes it feel fun.
content: Connections is a daily game about finding common threads between words. Players must select four groups of four words without making more than four mistakes. Connections beta opened on June 12.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: The Nature of Joy
description: We all exist in a magnificent, fragile body, beautiful and vulnerable at once.
content: NASHVILLE — Thanks to a Covid infection early in the pandemic, my blood pressure goes haywire when the temperature and dew point are both very high, and I have trouble breathing when the air quality is poor, too, so I stay indoors much of the summer now. But last Sunday I woke early to the most beautiful day in the history of the world, as my brother calls every day of his life. All around my yard, the world was renewing itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.7 Million Homes in California
description: An 1888 Craftsman home in Berkeley, a midcentury retreat in Palm Springs and a French Normandy house in Los Angeles.
content: This was one of the first homes built in Panoramic Hill, a neighborhood named for its sweeping views of the surrounding area and, on a clear day, San Francisco Bay. Built in the late 19th century, it was altered and moved to its present location in the early 20th century. Edward Taylor Parsons, an early owner, was a director of the Sierra Club and entertained important naturalists of the day in the library.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Putin Says Russia Is United Behind Him, After Quelling Rebellion
description: President Vladimir V. Putin spoke angrily of those who want “Russians to fight each other,” but his former ally, Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, said the mutiny he led was not a coup attempt.
content: A visibly angry Vladimir V. Putin on Monday denounced as “blackmail” a weekend rebellion by the Wagner mercenary group even as he defended his response to the mutiny and hinted at leniency for those who took part, saying that “the entire Russian society united” around his government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: While We Wait for the Supreme Court to Make Up Its Mind …
description: The fine print is what really matters when it comes to affirmative action.
content: Bret Stephens: Gail, I hope your summer is off to a great start. We’re in the season of Supreme Court decisions, waiting any day for the Harvard and U.N.C. ruling to come down. Assuming the court overturns affirmative action for private and public universities, and maybe beyond that, what do you think the effect will be?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Inside Yevgeny Prigozhin’s Money-Making Machine
description: The man who led a rebellion against President Vladimir Putin built a multinational commercial enterprise that helped fund his military operations.
content: Global markets are fairly calm on Monday morning after a weekend of turmoil in Russia. And there’s been no word from either President Vladimir Putin of Russia or his rebellious military chief-for-hire, Yevgeny Prigozhin, after Mr. Prigozhin’s aborted march on Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Review: ‘The Bear’ Changes Course(s)
description: Season 2 of the restaurant dramedy is more uplifting, more team-focused and more magnificent.
content: This review discusses plot points throughout Season 2 of FX’s “The Bear,” now airing in full on Hulu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: In a First, Germany’s Far Right AfD Party Will Take Control of a District
description: The election victory was a breakthrough for the Alternative for Germany party: It gained a majority in a district, albeit a tiny one, and will have bureaucratic authority over it.
content: A candidate for the resurgent far-right party Alternative for Germany has won a district administrator seat, the first time since the party was founded a decade ago that it has captured such a prominent regional post.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Sarah Ferguson, Duchess of York, Had Surgery for Breast Cancer
description: Ms. Ferguson, the ex-wife of Prince Andrew, had a single mastectomy after a routine mammogram. A spokesperson said her prognosis was good.
content: Sarah Ferguson, the Duchess of York and ex-wife of Prince Andrew, the disgraced son of Queen Elizabeth II, underwent a single mastectomy after a breast cancer diagnosis, she said during an episode of her podcast that was released Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Judge Denies Request to Seal Witness List in Trump Documents Case
description: The order by Judge Aileen Cannon means the identities of some or all of the Justice Department’s 84 potential witnesses in the case against the former president could become public.
content: The federal judge overseeing former President Donald J. Trump’s prosecution on charges of illegally holding on to sensitive national security documents denied on Monday the government’s request to keep secret a list of witnesses with whom Mr. Trump has been barred from discussing his case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: In Classrooms, Teachers Put A.I. Tutoring Bots to the Test
description: Newark public schools are cautiously trying out a new automated teaching aid from Khan Academy. The preliminary report card: “could use improvement.”
content: On a recent morning, Cheryl Drakeford, a third-grade teacher at First Avenue Elementary School in Newark, projected a challenging math question on her classroom’s whiteboard: “What fraction of the letters in the word MATHEMATICIAN are consonants?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘Invisible’ Review: Brown, British and Overlooked
description: As part of the Brits Off Broadway festival at 59E59 Theaters, Nikhil Parmar’s solo play is a drama-tinged satire that morphs into a grisly revenge parable.
content: In the world of Nikhil Parmar’s funny, fantastical solo play “Invisible,” the mind-set of Britain has undergone a significant shift. One of the West’s favorite boogeymen — the Islamic fundamentalist — has vanished from the public imagination. Chinese terrorists are the designated bad guys now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Deal for Formula 1 Team Reflects Growing U.S. Interest in the Sport
description: The actor Ryan Reynolds, the private equity firm RedBird Capital and Otro Capital are among the investors taking a stake in Renault’s Alpine team.
content: As media companies and big technology firms vie for sports viewers, investors have begun to look beyond the traditional avenues to teams and sports that only a few years ago had low profiles in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Expresses Confidence on the Economy. Voters May Be Skeptical.
description: President Biden believes that focusing on the economy will help his campaign for a second term, despite inflation and high interest rates.
content: President Biden has grown confident enough in the economy he leads — despite continuing inflation and high interest rates — that he is campaigning for re-election by eagerly attaching the name “Bidenomics” to his approach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adrian J. Rivera
title: ‘Flamin’ Hot’ Is So Bad, It Burns
description: By depicting a world in which Latinos need the approval of white people to feel good about ourselves, it reinforces the myth of white superiority.
content: “Flamin’ Hot,” a movie released this month and recently screened on the South Lawn of the White House, is a piece of propaganda designed to make Mexican Americans, and Latinos more broadly, feel good about ourselves. There’s nothing inherently wrong with creating a film that seeks to make a person or a group feel good. (See: the genre of feel-good movies.) It can even be affirming to see yourself reflected in various media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: A.I. May Someday Work Medical Miracles. For Now, It Helps Do Paperwork.
description: The best use for generative A.I. in health care, doctors say, is to ease the heavy burden of documentation that takes them hours a day and contributes to burnout.
content: Dr. Matthew Hitchcock, a family physician in Chattanooga, Tenn., has an A.I. helper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen and Noriko Hayashi
title: In Isolated Guam, Abortion Is Legal. And Nearly Impossible to Get.
description: The tiny U.S. territory in the western Pacific Ocean is thousands of miles from the nearest state, and has no resident doctors who perform abortions. Court decisions could cut access to pills, the only legal option left.
content: For decades, the Pregnancy Control Clinic, tucked inside a squat, beige building around the corner from a bowling alley, handled most of the abortions on Guam, a tiny U.S. territory 1,600 miles south of Japan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: ‘The Idol’ Season 1, Episode 4 Recap: Just a Jealous Guy
description: Destiny goes undercover as tensions rise at Jocelyn’s mansion. Tedros’s hair evolves from rattail to ponytail.
content: On the track that plays over opening and closing of this week’s episode of “The Idol,” the Weeknd sings: “I didn’t mean to hurt you. I’m sorry that I made you cry. I didn’t mean to hurt you. I’m just a jealous guy.” It’s the classic text of an abuser now made to sound pretty in Abel Tesfaye’s sensitive warble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Review: In ‘The Gospel According to Heather,’ the Messiah Has Homeroom
description: A lonely high school student discovers she may be a divine messenger in Paul Gordon’s half-baked new Off Broadway musical.
content: “Do you like Kierkegaard?” As flirtatious chit-chat goes, this one sets 17-year-old Heather (Brittany Nicole Williams) apart. You can also see why the jock she’s asking (Carlos Alcala) just walks away. Sadly, this is par for the course for Heather, a pescatarian brainiac who is ostracized by classmates at her Ohio high school for being a “freak,” and quietly stifled at home by a loving but clueless widowed mother (Lauren Elder).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William J. Broad
title: The Terror of Threes in the Heavens and on Earth
description: Physicists have long explored how phenomena in groups of three can sow chaos. A new three-body problem, they warn, could lead to not only global races for new armaments but also thermonuclear war.
content: Isaac Newton was baffled. He was already famous for discovering how gravity holds the universe together and for using that knowledge to predict the movements of celestial bodies, such as the moon’s path around the Earth. Now, by taking the sun’s gravitational tugs into account, he sought to improve his lunar predictions. Instead, it made them worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Princess Leia’s Dress From the Original ‘Star Wars’ Is Up for Bids
description: A ceremonial gown worn by Carrie Fisher was believed to be destroyed after the production of “A New Hope,” but it was recently found in an attic and restored.
content: The long, white dress worn by Carrie Fisher as Princess Leia in the final scene of the original 1977 “Star Wars” movie, “A New Hope,” was once thought to have been long gone, destroyed after the film’s production.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez
title: Trapped in the Crossfire of the U.S.-China Rivalry
description: Suriname, a tiny nation ravaged by recession, inflation and impossible debts, saw its relief held up by superpower politics. It won’t be the only country.
content: Inside his capacious office, his tan curtains drawn against the tropical sun, the president of Suriname expressed sympathy with the striking teachers who were massing outside, taunting him while demanding higher wages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Conditions at Guantánamo Are Cruel and Inhuman, U.N. Investigation Finds
description: The report was the result of the first visit by an independent human rights investigator to the prison in its two-decade history.
content: The last 30 detainees at Guantánamo Bay, including the men accused of plotting the Sept. 11 attacks, are being held by the United States under circumstances that constitute “cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment under international law,” a United Nations human rights investigator said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coco Romack
title: Sally Saul Is Finally in Control
description: At 77, the artist’s clay sculptures are fiercer than ever.
content: Entering the sculptor Sally Saul’s studio in Germantown, N.Y., two hours north of New York City, it feels as though you’ve happened upon some strange conference between man and animal. There is very little hanging on the white walls of the work space, which occupies the first of two floors in a building that, covered with green corrugated metal, resembles an upgraded shed. But across the floor and atop tables are lumpy earthen depictions of tree-dwelling creatures beside prominent historical figures like the American novelist Gertrude Stein. The cross-species interactions are mostly benign, as in a vignette where a girl seated on a stump is flanked by two kind-looking roosters. But some have more of an editorializing bite: To address her frustrations with Supreme Court Justice Samuel Alito’s abortion rulings, Saul cast him as being eternally tormented by three pudgy spiders. “Some pieces are sweeter, and then I think, ‘I want to make something that’s fiercer,’” she says. “I go back and forth.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: A New Penn Station Is Coming, With or Without Office Towers, Hochul Says
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul has severed ties with the development plan that relied on the building of office towers by Vornado Realty Trust.
content: The proposed $7 billion overhaul of Pennsylvania Station in New York City will go forward with or without the development of several office towers that were supposed to help pay for the project, Gov. Kathy Hochul said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Entries for the week of June 19, 2023.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes. It is probably also worth mentioning that the Diary is a work of fiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil and Michael Crowley
title: The U.S. and its allies had ‘nothing to do with’ the rebellion in Russia, Biden says.
description: Western nations agreed on a conference call not to let President Vladimir Putin of Russia blame them for the short-lived uprising, the American president said.
content: The United States and its allies had “nothing to do with” the Wagner mercenary group’s uprising against President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and his military command, President Biden said on Monday, his first public comments on the short-lived rebellion that incited an extraordinary weekend of crisis in Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Biden and Putin Have Dueling Messages on the Mutiny in Russia
description: The White House concluded that it had to get ahead of any argument by Vladimir V. Putin that the uprising was serving the interests of Russia’s adversaries.
content: When President Vladimir V. Putin spoke on Monday about the rebellion that threatened Moscow, and his rule, he started just as President Biden and his national security aides anticipated: blaming the United States for cheering on the uprising that the Russian leader said was intended to tear his country apart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: John B. Goodenough, 100, Dies; Nobel-Winning Creator of the Lithium-Ion Battery
description: An unassuming professor who remained active into his 90s, he is credited with the breakthrough that gave rise to the batteries powering today’s electronic devices.
content: John B. Goodenough, the scientist who shared the 2019 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for his crucial role in developing the revolutionary lithium-ion battery, the rechargeable power pack that is ubiquitous in today’s wireless electronic devices and electric and hybrid vehicles, died on Sunday at an assisted living facility in Austin, Texas. He was 100.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: The Most Expensive Team in Baseball Is Not Getting Any Better
description: For the Mets, another dispiriting defeat felt like more of the same. “Hopefully,” one Met said, “there’s light at the end of the tunnel.”
content: Nearly halfway through the 2023 season, the most expensive team in Major League Baseball history is closer to last place than first. After a dispiriting 7-6 loss to the Philadelphia Phillies on Sunday, the Mets and their nearly $500 million roster — once luxury taxes are considered — were left with a 35-42 record, dwindling odds of reaching the playoffs and a growing number of questions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: The fallout from an attempted mutiny in Russia.
content: Confusion and uncertainty pervaded Russia yesterday, with neither Vladimir Putin, the Russian president, nor Yevgeny Prigozhin, the leader of a mercenary force known as Wagner, appearing in public the day after an open military rebellion led by Prigozhin appeared defused. (Here’s how the mutiny unfolded.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Joseph Johnson
title: Opposition Accuses Sierra Leone’s Military of Election Weekend Assault
description: Supporters and party officials from the All People’s Congress were sifting through polling data from the presidential vote when the military surrounded party headquarters.
content: DAKAR, Senegal — Senior officials from Sierra Leone’s main opposition party on Sunday accused the country’s military of shooting live ammunition and tear gas into their headquarters, raising tensions in the small West African nation a day after presidential elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: A Pill Form of Ozempic Is on the Horizon
description: Research published Sunday evaluates the effectiveness of the active ingredient in injectable diabetes and obesity drugs when taken orally.
content: The next iteration of Ozempic and Wegovy — the much-discussed, hard-to-obtain injectable medications known for their ability to induce weight loss — may come in pill form.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Why Mark Ruffalo and Wendell Pierce Are Fighting for a Crumbling Church
description: Congregants of the West Park Presbyterian Church, a Manhattan landmark, want it torn down and replaced by condos. Celebrities are joining the fight to save it.
content: For years, a conflict over whether to tear down one of New York City’s historic churches, a 19th-century Romanesque Revival building on the Upper West Side, has been cast in epic terms, as a battle between the little people and big business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Putin condemns the Wagner revolt as a failure
description: Tonight, watch the new season of “The Bachelorette”
content: Speaking publicly for the first time in two days, a visibly angry President Vladimir Putin denounced as “blackmail” a weekend rebellion by the Wagner mercenary group but suggested leniency for the fighters who took part.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter and Elizabeth A. Harris
title: How Review-Bombing Can Tank a Book Before It’s Published
description: The website Goodreads has become an essential avenue for building readership, but the same features that help generate excitement can also backfire.
content: Cecilia Rabess figured her debut novel, “Everything’s Fine,” would spark criticism: The story centers on a young Black woman working at Goldman Sachs who falls in love with a conservative white co-worker with bigoted views.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jody García and Simon Romero
title: What an Election Surprise in Central America Means for Democracy
description: Bernardo Arévalo, a professorial lawmaker, stunned Guatemala’s establishment by advancing to a second round against Sandra Torres, a former first lady.
content: Judges and prosecutors driven from the country. Independent news media under attack. Top presidential candidates barred from running.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: Harsh New Fentanyl Laws, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Let’s Talk About the Bathroom Scene
description: Bodily functions rarely get the spotlight in fiction and poetry. But for some writers, they drive action and help create indelible characters.
content: Alfred Hitchcock once told François Truffaut he wanted to make a film that would examine a city entirely through food and, unusually, waste. He would show the arrival of meat and produce into a metropolis, “its distribution, the selling, how it’s fixed up and absorbed. And gradually, the end of the film would show the sewers, and the garbage being dumped out into the ocean.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serge Schmemann
title: Prigozhin and the Long and Infamous History of Failed Russian Rebellions
description: Putin may emerge weakened, strengthened or vindictive.
content: Whatever Yevgeny Prigozhin intended his rebellion to achieve, it proved short and senseless. Less than 24 hours after he sent his tanks and troops trundling on the main highway toward Moscow, the mercenary chief was persuaded to turn them around and take refuge himself in Belarus. The question now is what will happen in the next act, particularly whether the failed mutiny will leave President Vladimir Putin weakened, strengthened or vindictive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Diwali Is Set to Become a School Holiday in New York City
description: Local officials called the decision to close schools in honor of Diwali a victory for the thousands of New Yorkers who celebrate.
content: Diwali, the South Asian Festival of Lights, is set to become a public school holiday in New York City, Mayor Eric Adams announced on Monday, calling the moment a major victory for local families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy and Kelley Manley
title: Club Q Shooter Pleads Guilty in Court
description: A plea deal means the 23-year-old shooter will spend a lifetime in prison for a rampage at an L.G.B.T.Q. bar in Colorado Springs last year that left five people dead.
content: The 23-year-old assailant who carried out a deadly shooting rampage at Club Q in Colorado Springs pleaded guilty on Monday to dozens of charges of murder and attempted murder, avoiding a prolonged trial over an attack on members of the L.G.B.T.Q. community.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Worrying About the Judge and the Jury for Trump’s Trial
description: Readers fear that the judge may be biased and the jury intimidated. Also: The revolt in Russia; migrants and New York’s suburbs; climate education.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Mike Baker
title: Prosecutors to Seek Death Penalty in Idaho Murders Case
description: The top prosecutor in Latah County said the November killings met the standard for the kind of aggravating factors that warrant seeking the death penalty.
content: Prosecutors in Idaho said they planned to seek the death penalty against the man accused of murdering four University of Idaho students in a home near campus last fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: The Strongest Bone
description: “Gruesome? Perhaps, but I need something of you with me, and this will have to do.”
content: This week’s stunning Modern Love essay is one of the most striking, human and moving essays I’ve had the pleasure of coming across in our ever-growing submission inbox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: In his first remarks since his revolt, Prigozhin claims he wasn’t trying to overthrow Putin.
description: The Kremlin had said an investigation into Yevgeny V. Prigozhin’s role in the brief uprising against Russia’s military command was dropped, but Russian news media reports say the case remains open.
content: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the leader of the Wagner mercenary group who mounted a brief uprising against Russia’s military command over the weekend, broke a long period of silence on Monday to deny, once more, that he had any intention of seizing power with his march on Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: The Republican Field Is Heading to New Hampshire
description: Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis and other presidential candidates are traveling to the Granite State this week.
content: Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis and other presidential candidates are traveling to the Granite State this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dodai Stewart
title: DMs From New York City
description: If you know where to look — down in the subway, up on a light pole, inside a taxi — you’ll find messages from New Yorkers trying hard to make themselves heard.
content: If you know where to look — down in the subway, up on a light pole, inside a taxi — you’ll find messages from New Yorkers trying hard to make themselves heard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: An Exhibit Chronicles the Fight for 15
description: The exhibit features items worn or carried by labor advocates from around the world.
content: The exhibit features items worn or carried by labor advocates from around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Do You Know These Comics and Their Specific Screen Adaptations?
description: Many summer blockbusters and streaming hot television shows started as comic books. Try this quiz to test your knowledge on the topic.
content: Many summer blockbusters and streaming hot television shows started as comic books. Try this quiz to test your knowledge on the topic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Addario
title: A Boy’s Life on the Front Lines
description: In a Ukrainian town once teeming with families, an 11-year-old navigates a childhood transformed by war.
content: In a Ukrainian town once teeming with families, an 11-year-old navigates a childhood transformed by war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Putin Forcefully Rebukes Wagner’s Rebellion in National Address
description: In a taped speech released by Russian state media, President Vladimir V. Putin said he gave direct instructions to avoid bloodshed during the mercenaries’ brief revolt and thanked his military.
content: In a taped speech released by Russian state media, President Vladimir V. Putin said he gave direct instructions to avoid bloodshed during the mercenaries’ brief revolt and thanked his military.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: U.S. and Allies ‘Were Not Involved’ in Russia Revolt, Biden Says
description: President Biden said the United States and its NATO allies had “nothing to do with” a rebellion by the Wagner mercenary group in Russia.
content: President Biden said the United States and its NATO allies had “nothing to do with” a rebellion by the Wagner mercenary group in Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: DeSantis Proposes Using Force on Suspected Drug Traffickers
description: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida proposed a series of hard-right immigration policies during a campaign stop in Texas.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida proposed a series of hard-right immigration policies during a campaign stop in Texas.
source.name: The New York Times
